awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  Open hardware for aquatic germplasm preservation
awd_abstract_narration:
Investments in aquatic species around the world support the annual production of more than 110 million tons of food, the direct employment of more than 60 million people, and the support many types of scientific research including medicine. Valuable genetic lines of aquatic species, such as fast-growing species for fish farmers (aquaculture) or endangered species, must be preserved in a way that can be recovered years, decades, or even longer after they are collected. Cryopreservation (freezing) is a valuable tool to protect these resources, but it must be done in a standardized way with devices and approaches that can fit all budgets. A new approach is to use 3D printing and consumer-level electronics to produce devices that users can manufacture themselves. This “open hardware” needs to be made accessible to new user and maker communities. This project will develop an Open Hardware Ecosystems in which users can access files to make devices and help shape future developments. This Ecosystem will allow laboratories, stock centers, academic institutions, aquaculture producers, and conservation agencies to preserve and distribute genetic material for future development.  

Open-source hardware offers tremendous opportunities for science to expand participation and improve outcomes. This project seeks to establish germplasm repositories to safeguard the genetic resources of aquatic species. A strategy based on the principles of business development is needed for creation of an efficient Open Hardware Ecosystem to avoid pitfalls and to generate opportunities by identifying time, resources, costs, and personnel needed to maintain and use the Ecosystem. Useful platforms should be able to distribute fabrication files for open hardware, as well as the associated user manuals, data collection worksheets, database structures, training curriculum, and other information needed to produce repository-ready samples. This project will be user-based and will focus on the process for recruitment leading to community development, and the progression through user to maker to developer. This planning stage will include a determination of the size and characteristics of the target sectors, while identifying opportunities for expansion. Process mapping approaches will be used to develop simulation modeling and analysis of the proposed platform. These options will allow for open distribution of technology, while maintaining protection of intellectual property.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
1. An electronic platform for open-source distribution and training was established. The platform is a Learning Management System (LMS) with file storage and exchange that will be the core of distribution of open-source hardware including fabrication files, assembly instructions, user manuals, checklists, spreadsheets and other instructional materials. The Course for the Cajun Ejector along with the necessary files is already loaded on the platform, and it is being used as a proof-of-concept case. A second course in animal husbandry was integrated into the LMS, as an example of training courses. These courses will allow us to gather data on the time that users interact with the LMS, the number of times the platform is accessed, and to gather feedback on platform performance. This information will help the team make decisions about improvements to satisfy the needs of different users. Onboarding protocols have been put in place for new users. This platform can be accessed at https://lms.aggrc.com/. The Cajun Ejector has already been deployed on the platform, and other content is currently being added. The fabrication files are currently hosted at https://3d.nih.gov/users/aggrc.lsuac and will be made available in the training platform and the AGGRC website (AGGRC.com). 
2. Several collaborators from the original target population have received open-source devices, tested them in their operations and have provided feedback, thus becoming users. Two of the collaborators have acquired their own 3D printers and have become makers, based on the designs that the AGGRC has developed. One of the collaborators has started to design their own devices and are using them in their operations. 
3. The initial target population was increased to include other research centers and members within the conservation and aquaculture sectors, nationally and internationally. 
4. Process maps were used to determine applications where open-source hardware can be used and the resources needed by collaborators to become users and makers. This will help us to develop simulation modelling approaches to guide future development of the open0source environment. 
5. The needs of multiple stakeholder groups were assessed providing a clear consensus on the need for training materials and centers to assist participation of new and current users on the processes required for the use of open hardware for germplasm conservation.  
6. After interviews and feedback from the target communities, we decided to pivot from the initial approach using only open hardware, to development of comprehensive kits (packages) that contain all other necessary components. This is harder but will ensure greater reproducibility and expand participation. We initially thought of these as “technology packages” but evolved our thinking to see them as “capability packages” to focus on the needs of the users rather than just the contents of the packages. These capability packages will include the open hardware devices as well as all the materials needed to use them including instructions. We will also provide QR codes for device design files and instructions. 
7. Workshops were conducted to gain insight and solicit feedback with directors of the five NIH national aquatic biomedical stock centers (Ambystoma Genetic Stock Center (AGSC), National Resource for Aplysia (NRA), National Xenopus Resource (NXR), Zebrafish International Resource Center (ZIRC), Xiphophorus Genetic Stock Center (XGSC), and other stakeholders such as the National Center for Marine Algae and Microbiota in Bigelow (NCMA). Collaborations were developed with commercial partners such as Primo Broodstock USA, LLC, and Sol Azul (oyster farm, Mexico), and a multi-institutional program, the Reef Restoration and Adaptation Program, in Australia. Multiple other institutions have been visited in person or through virtual meetings to gauge their interest in the Open Hardware Environment for germplasm preservation. 
8. An initial licensing scheme (CC BY-SA, Creativecommons.org) has been selected. This will be evaluated continuously as the open-source environment grows with the advisory council and the office of intellectual property of the university. 


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Terrence R Tiersch
